segment.source: Understand AppLocker enforcement settings (Windows 10)
segment.target: Understand AppLocker enforcement settings (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic describes the AppLocker enforcement settings for rule collections.
segment.target: This topic describes the AppLocker enforcement settings for rule collections.

segment.source: Understand AppLocker enforcement settings
segment.target: Understand AppLocker enforcement settings

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic describes the AppLocker enforcement settings for rule collections.
segment.target: This topic describes the AppLocker enforcement settings for rule collections.

segment.source: Rule enforcement is applied only to a collection of rules, not to individual rules.
segment.target: Rule enforcement is applied only to a collection of rules, not to individual rules.

segment.source: AppLocker divides the rules into four collections: executable files, Windows Installer files, scripts, and DLL files.
segment.target: AppLocker divides the rules into four collections: executable files, Windows Installer files, scripts, and DLL files.

segment.source: For more info about rule collections, see Understanding AppLocker rule collections.
segment.target: For more info about rule collections, see Understanding AppLocker rule collections.

segment.source: By default, if enforcement is not configured and rules are present in a rule collection, those rules are enforced.
segment.target: By default, if enforcement is not configured and rules are present in a rule collection, those rules are enforced.

segment.source: The following table details the three AppLocker rule enforcement settings in Group Policy for each rule collection.
segment.target: The following table details the three AppLocker rule enforcement settings in Group Policy for each rule collection.

segment.source: Enforcement setting
segment.target: Enforcement setting

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Not configured
segment.target: Not configured

segment.source: By default, enforcement is not configured in a rule collection.
segment.target: By default, enforcement is not configured in a rule collection.

segment.source: If rules are present in the corresponding rule collection, they are enforced.
segment.target: If rules are present in the corresponding rule collection, they are enforced.

segment.source: If rule enforcement is configured in a higher-level linked Group Policy object (GPO), that enforcement value overrides the Not configured value.
segment.target: If rule enforcement is configured in a higher-level linked Group Policy object (GPO), that enforcement value overrides the Not configured value.

segment.source: Enforce rules
segment.target: Enforce rules

segment.source: Rules are enforced for the rule collection, and all rule events are audited.
segment.target: Rules are enforced for the rule collection, and all rule events are audited.

segment.source: Audit only
segment.target: Audit only

segment.source: Rule events are audited only.
segment.target: Rule events are audited only.

segment.source: Use this value when planning and testing AppLocker rules.
segment.target: Use this value when planning and testing AppLocker rules.

segment.source: For the AppLocker policy to be enforced on a device, the Application Identity service must be running.
segment.target: For the AppLocker policy to be enforced on a device, the Application Identity service must be running.

segment.source: For more info about the Application Identity service, see Configure the Application Identity service.
segment.target: For more info about the Application Identity service, see Configure the Application Identity service.

segment.source: When AppLocker policies from various GPOs are merged, the enforcement modes are merged by using the standard Group Policy order of inheritance, which is local, domain, site, and organizational unit (OU).
segment.target: When AppLocker policies from various GPOs are merged, the enforcement modes are merged by using the standard Group Policy order of inheritance, which is local, domain, site, and organizational unit (OU).

segment.source: The Group Policy setting that was last written or applied by order of inheritance is used for the enforcement mode, and all rules from linked GPOs are applied.
segment.target: The Group Policy setting that was last written or applied by order of inheritance is used for the enforcement mode, and all rules from linked GPOs are applied.
